ThingDef.label: Smith Carbine
ThingDef.description:
Smith Carbine. Lightweight Simplistic Breech-Loading carbine designed to be easily reloaded on horseback. Uses a unique rubber cased cartridge along with a separate percussion cap.

“In every battle, there comes a time when both sides consider themselves beaten, then he who continues the attack wins."
-U.S. Grant

ThingDef.label: Colt M1841 Ring Lever
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .36 Caliber Ball. 8-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.label: Hall Carbine
ThingDef.description:
Hall Carbine. The first widely adopted military breech-loader, the Hall pattern rifle was an impressive sight for the time, reloading much faster then the traditional muzzle-loading musket. This model is a short, lightweight, smoothbore carbine in .69 caliber, not rifled in order to keep the ability to shoot a buckshot load.

“I have not yet begun to fight.”
-John Paul Jones

ThingDef.label: Maynard M1851 Carbine
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .50 Caliber Ball. 1-round chamber. Single-Shot.

ThingDef.label: Colt M1855 Revolving Rifle
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .44 Caliber Ball. 6-round cylinder. Single-Action.

ThingDef.label: Sharps M1859 Carbine
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .52 Caliber Ball. 1-round chamber. Single-Shot.

ThingDef.label: Burnside M1860 Carbine
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .54 Caliber Ball. 1-round chamber. Single-Shot.

ThingDef.label: Spencer M1860 Carbine
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .56-56 Spencer. 7-round tube. Lever-Action.

ThingDef.label: Henry Rifle
ThingDef.description: Henry Model 1860. Simplistic lever action rifle chambered in a relatively weak .44 rimfire round. The Henry Rifle is the ancestor of the most lever action rifles.

ThingDef.label: Henry M1860 Sniper
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .44 Henry. 15-round tube. Lever-Action.

ThingDef.label: Sharps M1863 Carbine
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .52 Caliber Ball. 1-round chamber. Single-Shot.

ThingDef.label: Palmer M1865 Carbine
ThingDef.description: Caliber: .56-56 Spencer. 1-round chamber. Single-Shot. A predecessor of bolt-action rifles.

ThingDef.label: Winchester 1866
ThingDef.description: Iconic first lever-action from Winchester proceeding from the Henry was an intimidating feat, however the 1866, nick-named "Yellow-boy" did just that. With improved ergonomics and an improved loading systems, it provided for quick and rapid fire under duress.

ThingDef.label: Winchester 1873 Trapper
ThingDef.description: Winchester Model 1873. Chambered in the intermediate .44-40 caliber round.

ThingDef.label: New Model Evans Carbine
ThingDef.description: USA. The Evens rifle is a lesser known repeater make in the mid 1800s. Its magazine size is impressive for the time but its special mechanism make it a slow to reload and expensive to manufacture. Originally chambered in 44 Evens, this model is chambered in 44-40.

ThingDef.label: Whitney-Burgess
ThingDef.description: Burgess 1878. lightweight lever action carbine, chambered in the reliable 45-70 Government cartridge.

ThingDef.label: Winchester 1885 "Highwall"
ThingDef.description: The Highwall. Chambered in 50-110WCF that can down an elephant, this rifle is suitable for all your big hunting needs. Just make the one shot count.

ThingDef.label: Winchester 1885 "Highwall" Sniper
ThingDef.description: The Highwall. Chambered in a .50-110 round that can down an elephant, this rifle is suitable for all your big hunting needs. Just make the one shot count.

ThingDef.label: Winchester Model 1886
ThingDef.description: Ancient lever-action repeating rifle chambered in a powerful rifle cartridge.

ThingDef.label: Winchester 1886 Express
ThingDef.description: Winchester Model 1886 Express. Heavy duty lever action rifle. Its ingenious design features a strong frame, and action letting the rifle use high-velocity smokeless ammunition with no issues. This model is chambered in the powerfull .50-110 caliber and features highly accurate target sights.

ThingDef.label: Winchester '94
ThingDef.description: Ancient lever-action repeating rifle that became one of the most famous and popular hunting rifles of all time.

ThingDef.label: Sharps 1874
ThingDef.description: The 1874 Sharps, no doubt one of the most popular rifle for large game hunting, with a powerful cartridge, and heavy barrel. This rifle is accurate and deadly.

ThingDef.label: Winchester 1895 US
ThingDef.description: This lever gun finally strayed away from the tube magazine system. Instead adopting the increasingly popular top fed design. The ability to maintain a sight picture while shooting gives the gun an advantage on the field.
